Learn More & Join Download Assignment PDF Before You Shoot â€¢ Choose a narrative or theme that you want to explore in your triptych. â€¢ Scout locations that fit your chosen theme and visualize how each panel will relate to one another. â€¢ Gather props or subjects that will help convey your story across the three images. â€¢ Plan your shooting schedule to ensure you have adequate time for each panel. â€¢ Review the principles of composition and how they can be applied to triptychs. The Assignment Technical Focus â€¢ Use aperture priority mode at f/5.6 with ISO 200 fixed, allowing the camera to adjust shutter speed for optimal exposure. â€¢ Consider using a tripod to maintain consistent framing across all three images. â€¢ Experiment with depth of field by adjusting aperture to emphasize your subject in each panel. â€¢ Ensure proper lighting for each shot to maintain a cohesive tone throughout the triptych. â€¢ Think about the angles and perspectives that will create a visual flow from one image to the next. Creative Focus â€¢ Explore how color palettes can unify your triptych and create emotional resonance. â€¢ Use leading lines in your compositions to guide the viewer's eye across the three panels. â€¢ Incorporate contrasting elements in each image to highlight the narrative or theme. â€¢ Experiment with different focal lengths to add variety while maintaining coherence. â€¢ Think about the relationship between the left and right images and how they point to the center image. Assignment Tasks â€¢ Create three images that together tell a story of growth: the beginning, middle, and end stages of a plant's life cycle, using aperture priority mode at f/4 with ISO 200 fixed. â€¢ Photograph a triptych representing a day in the life of a city, capturing the morning, afternoon, and evening scenes, using aperture priority mode at f/8 with ISO 200 fixed. â€¢ Document a personal journey or experience in three parts, ensuring each image reflects a different emotional state, using shutter priority mode at 1/250s with ISO 200 fixed. â€¢ Capture three related objects that represent a theme of change, ensuring each image has a distinct perspective while maintaining coherence, using aperture priority mode at f/2.8 with ISO 200 fixed. â€¢ Photograph a dynamic event in three stages: the buildup, the climax, and the aftermath, using shutter priority mode at 1/500s with ISO 200 fixed. â€¢ Create a triptych that explores a color theme, with each panel focusing on a different shade while maintaining a cohesive subject, using aperture priority mode at f/5 with ISO 200 fixed. ðŸ’¡ Stretch Tasks â€¢ Create a series of triptychs that explore the same theme but through different photographic techniques, such as long exposure versus freeze motion. â€¢ Collaborate with another photographer to each create triptychs from the same subject matter, comparing styles and interpretations. DON'T â€¢ âœ— Don't select unrelated subjects for your triptych. â€¢ âœ— Don't neglect the importance of visual flow between the images. â€¢ âœ— Don't rely solely on post-editing to create coherence; focus on composition during shooting. â€¢ âœ— Don't forget to maintain a consistent style across all three images. â€¢ âœ— Don't rush the process; take your time to plan each photograph.
